title-group.article-title: Airfreight Transport and Economic Development: An Examination of Causality

author-notes.corresp: Kenneth Button and Junyang Yuan are in the School of Public Policy, George Mason University, MS-3B1, 3351 Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA 2220, USA. E-mail: kbutton@gmu.edu and yjunyang@masonlive.gmu.edu.

abstract.p: The paper examines the potential role that airfreight transport in the US can play in stimulating local and regional economic development. The analysis examines trends in employment and income for metropolitan statistical areas that make use of airfreight services. The focus is on causality, and not on simple correlation, and uses econometric analysis rather than simpler economic multiplier approaches. Granger causality testing based on panel data covering 35 airport and 32 metropolitan statistical areas in the US from 1990 to 2009 indicates that airfreight transport was a positive driver for local economic development. The conclusions focus on the strengths but also the weaknesses of the methodology for assessing causality.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Economists have a poor record in terms of explaining and forecasting economic growth. This is true at the national, regional and local levels of spatial aggregation. From a public policy perspective, understanding the economic implications of such things as public expenditure and regulations on the economic performance of an area is important if social efficiency targets are to be achieved. Much of what has traditionally been accepted as being important in achieving economic growth has had little empirical basis and any links between public policies and the performance of an economy have generally been found ex post. The problem ex ante has not been a shortage of theories, but rather a surplus with little consensus on which is the most relevant. The theories that dominate the debate can be broadly divided in two. The neo-classical view is that it is inputs into the economy that lead to economic growth and that, as input prices change, so economies converge to a common growth rate. The alternative view, the endogenous growth theory, argues that regions that are growing faster will, with any policy intervention, attract more and more resources and there will be a continuing divergence in economic growth rates (Button, 2011).

Transport investment and policy have been important in these debates, because empirical study of their impacts can offer some guidance as to the relevance of the alternative growth theories. High quality transport facilitates trade between regions, and the movement of factors of production, such as labour and raw materials. From an economic development perspective, if the neo-classical theory is valid then this would lead towards equalisation of prices and incomes in regions and between regions; unemployed and low-income workers, for example, would move to more prosperous areas, increasing wages in their originating region and reducing them in the receiving region. A sudden injection of appropriate public transport investment would act as a positive shock. The endogenous growth theory would support an alternative position: namely, that growth in a region would supply the resources for investment that would set in motion a series of further ripples stimulating additional growth. Basically, the economic growth in a region generates the resources for infrastructure investment, rather than the transport investment leading to economic growth.

Aschauer’s (1989) empirical paper reinvigorated the debate about the role that public infrastructure, and in particular physical infrastructure, can play in increasing economic productivity. The strong positive correlation he found between investment in physical infrastructure and macroeconomic performance, however, has subsequently been vigorously debated and there has been an emerging consensus that his findings overstate the importance of public investments. The nature of these critiques has been varied but they include such things as: problems in defining and measuring infrastructure, aggregation bias,1 lack of consideration of the quality of investment, limited consideration of how infrastructure once built, is managed and maintained, and the lack of any real consideration of causality. Winston (1991) offers a useful overview of much of the debate.

This paper does not attempt to tackle all of these issues, but rather it focuses on a limited range of the criticisms and, in particular, those relating to causality and aggregation bias. It circumvents the latter by conducting analysis at the meso, regional level and focusing on a particular transport mode. This allows a focus on the causality question that is relevant for larger policy-making not only for assessing the strengths of the two competing schools of thought on economic development in general, but also in providing help in the assessment of particular transport policies at a local level.

sec.title: The Economic Impacts of Air Transport
sec.p: There has been increased interest in the macroeconomic role of airports and economic development as exemplified by work at the US Federal Aviation Administration (USFAA, 2008). This level of aggregation, however, moves away from the local ownership of most airports in the US and the interests of local governments. There is particular interest in ensuring that local services meet the needs of the community (van den Berg et al., 1996) and in exploiting the potential that airports may have for attracting business to the area (Nolan et al., 2005). There are also wider implications ranging from enhancing social cohesion to adverse impacts on the environment (see for example, TRB, 2009). This latter cost–benefit type analysis is not considered here; our focus is entirely on narrower ideas of economic impact analysis.

From a meso-economic perspective, airport investment or expansion of existing facilities, either passenger or air cargo, may have a number of potential implications for economic development in the surrounding region. These reflect the various stages in the development of a facility and have different effects over time. The implications of investing in airport infrastructure can thus be divided into four types, each with different temporal horizons (Button et al., 2010).

list-item.p: Primary effects are the short-term benefits to a region from the construction of an airport—the design of the facility, the building of the runways, the construction of the terminals and hangars, the installation of air traffic navigation systems and so on—and the resultant income and employment multipliers associated with this. These are largely short-term effects that have limited implications on the longer-term economic performance of a region. In addition, where specialised equipment or labour is required, this often is brought from outside the area reducing the size of the initial multiplicand.

Secondary effects are the local economic benefits of running and operating the airport—employment in maintaining the facility, in security, in handling the aircraft, cargo and passengers on the air side, in transporting people and cargo to and from the terminal, in the handling of customs and clearance, and so on. These secondary effects can be extremely important for some local economies in terms of employment, income and, for local government, taxation revenue. As more technology is introduced into airport operations embracing such things as electronic tagging and tracking of cargo, the scale of the secondary effect is, relative to the initial expenditures involved, likely to decline in the future.

Tertiary effects stem from the stimulus to a local economy resulting from firms and individuals having air transport services at their disposal. These differ for those firms located in or near hub cities, compared with those located at airports on a spoke or having no major carrier. Hubs are often cited as offering more direct flights favoured by business travellers, but this advantage is of less importance to many types of cargo traffic where just-on-time delivery is more important than routing. Yet the hub also benefits those on the spokes because without a hub-and-spoke structure many would find it difficult to travel long distances at all. Hubs allow interconnectivity. In the US, over half of the 15 000 city pairs served by a major carrier have less than one passenger per day. The large amount of cargo carried in belly holds means that users of this segment of the air market also benefit from hub structures.

Perpetuity effects mean that an airport can change the entire economic structure of a region—it can shift the production function of the surrounding economy. This is different from the tertiary effect that largely reflects a movement along the production function by expanding the opportunities for existing types of industry. This type of dynamic economic impact of an airport is the most abstract and the most difficult to quantify ex ante. It has been little researched, but examples can be seen in the transformation of small agricultural island economies into tourist destinations and the growth of high-technology regions around major airports, such as Dulles (Washington) and Logan (Boston) in the US, and the M4 corridor around Heathrow airport in the UK.

sec.p: Our concern here is very much with the last two categories of impact; these are seen as the main economic development effects of air transport. The traditional approaches to teasing these effects from prior experiences of airport developments, have involved a number of techniques, each with strengths and weaknesses. Academic assessments looking at the role of airports in regional development are, despite the policy interests, relatively sparse and much of the analysis has tended to be of a highly practical and limited nature.

The traditional way of trying to assess the role of airports in regional development, and one widely used by planning agencies, is through the use of regional multipliers using exogenously determined multipliers, for example in Virginia (Virginia Department of Aviation, 2004), Oregon (Oregon Department of Aviation, 2008) and South Carolina (South Carolina Department of Transportation, 2006). A new airport goes through the stages from its planning to becoming fully operational, and each generates it own particular type of income and employment multiplier effects. The challenge is to determine local multiplier effects that are notoriously difficult at the local level where economies are so open (Butler and Kiernan, 1992; Debbage, 2002). In addition, the recent analysis of US multipliers at the national level, where leakages are very much smaller than for states, still indicates a range of only 0.8 to 1.5 (Ramey, 2011).

Surveys are also widely used to try to elicit the views of experts on how affected parties, often stakeholders in addition to stockholders, are likely to respond to any change in air service provision. The difficulties are both to decide whom to question and then how to question them. The potential of ‘capture’ of the process by vested interests is large. Yet even if the ability to remove this bias exists, the complex interactions between the various actors, and the ways that they assume others will behave, make it difficult to frame useful questions. Delphi techniques, involving iterations of the responses through several rounds allowing participants to modify their answers, offer a partial but incomplete way of circumventing this problem. The development of experimental economics over the past 20 years or more offers a more rigorous methodology but it has yet to be applied to the role of airports.

The preferred method here is the use of econometric techniques that use statistical analysis to look at the impacts of air transport infrastructure on regional economies. The number of econometric studies of airports has in the past been relatively limited. They have often focused on some particular aspects of the link between an airport and economic development—for example, the studies by Button et al. (1999), of airports attracting high-technology industry in the US, and by Button and Taylor (2000) on international air services and regional growth—or on particular areas—for example, Bennell and Prentice (1993) on role of Canadian airports and Button et al. (2010) on small airports in Virginia. However, none of this work looks specifically at airfreight; indeed, the focus tends to be almost exclusively on passenger traffic. This is surprising because 25–30 per cent of US international trade by value (over $805 billion in 2009) is moved annually by air and, domestically, airfreight accounts for 5–6 per cent of the market.2

The approach can apportion things like job changes and income effects in a region between various factors, including airport capacity. It does, however, require considerable data, and specifying the appropriate model can be challenging. There does also remain the issue of causality—do airports increase the productivity of a region, or do productive regions have more resources to invest in airports? Green’s (2007) work addresses the nature of some of the issues involved and Button et al. (1999) used Granger causality tests3 to elicit that airport traffic leads development in terms of high-technology employment, but the methods are not ideal and data are not readily available. Nevertheless, the approach does allow a more rigorous examination of the links between air transport and economic development than the alternatives and does permit some testing of causality.

sec.title: The Methodology and Data
sec.p: Led by globalisation and time-based competition, the worlds of commerce and supply-chain management changed significantly. New products that are typically small, light, compact, high-value added and assembled, are increasingly shipped by air in a fast and flexible manner. Hence, this paper focuses on airfreight transport. As highlighted, there are numerous studies of the correlation between passenger commercial air transport and economic development, although few of these strictly consider causality. Airfreight transport has been given even less attention despite it being a mode of growing importance for the US economy as well as an important revenue source for many airlines. Quantitatively, airfreight carries nearly 40 per cent of world trade by value and is increasingly important in the movement of high-value/low-bulk products, of express packages and of perishables such as ‘exotic’ fruit and flowers. Figure 1 offers a picture of the physical scale of airfreight in the US; the upward trend is discernable despite cyclical, business-cycle-related fluctuations. Airfreight is carried either on dedicated aircraft or in the belly holds of what are normally considered passenger aircraft. With regard to modal share of merchandise American trade, air transport carried over 25 per cent in 2010 in terms of value, but only 0.4 per cent in terms of weight.4

Data source: Air cargo summary data, RITA, United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics (http://www.transtats.bts.gov/freight.asp?pn=1).

sec.p: The source of air cargo data used here is the TranStats database of the Research and Innovation Technology Administration of United States Department of Transportation.5 Data are available for American airports covering both inbound and outbound flights with freight and mail. The onward flight freight and mail data are used to exclude traffic that just passes through an airport, leaving inbound and outbound volume to be aggregated to reflect the amount of air cargo potentially germane to local economic development. Most large airports are located close to major urban centres and it is therefore difficult to define precisely the geographical range impacted by an airport. This introduces an obvious caveat to our use of metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) where large airports are located as the areas are likely to be influenced by several air services.

The difficulty in examining causality is that it traditionally requires a relatively long time-series of data and this is seldom available. The approach adopted here is to use a panel of airports over time to enrich the limited time-series data available for each airport. This is a relatively new approach to causality analysis, but it offers a pragmatic way of examining the issue by basically increasing degrees of freedom. Its primary use in the past has been mainly in macroeconomic analysis (Hsiao and Hsiao, 2006; Ferreira, 2009).

Based on accumulated air cargo volume between 1990 and 2009, the top 35 US domestic airports in the 48 contiguous states are adopted for analysis. Some of these lie in the same MSA, such as John F. Kennedy and Newark airports in the New York–Northern New Jersey–Long Island MSA, Miami and Fort Lauderdale airports in the Miami–Fort Lauderdale–Pompano Beach MSA and San Francisco and Oakland airports in the San Francisco–Oakland–Fremont MSA. There are thus 32 MSAs associated with the airports in our dataset. Because economic development can be assessed in a number of different ways, personal income, per capita personal income and employment in each MSA extracted from the United States Bureau of Economic Analysis are taken to represent its main dimensions.

There are some caveats with the data and in particular there were changes in reporting requirements in 2002 that brought more airlines into the sample and this could affect the continuity of the time-series to some extent. It is not felt, however, that this brought about a sea change in the database. In particular, because the changes would affect all air services in each cross-section in the same way, any temporal effects will be muted because of this in a panel data analysis.

Personal income and employment are often taken to reflect a region’s overall economic conditions, while per capita personal income is often taken to illustrate welfare level. Because gross domestic product data for MSAs are only available between 2001 and 2009, GDP is not considered. Hence, we construct a dataset including each MSA’s annual air cargo volume, personal income and per capita personal income, both in 1990 prices and employment covering 1990 to 2009 (see Table 1). All variables take the logarithm transformation to reduce the heterogeneity of variances.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The unit root tests demonstrate that the logarithm transformations of the four variables are stationary in their first-difference forms, indicating that these first-difference values qualify for Granger causality tests of stationary series. Eviews 6 software offers two ways of dealing with the pooled data’s Granger causality issues and both are deployed. Initially, we consider a pair-wise Granger causality test for binary variables, air cargo volume and each of three local economic variables, and then we conduct a VAR Granger causality/block exogeneity test for each combination. We find that the pair-wise Granger causality test produces results identical to those of the VAR Granger causality/block exogeneity test. Hence, Table 3 just displays the former.

sec.p: The table considers in turn, air cargo movements in relation to employment, personal income and per capita income in a region. Essentially, in the simplest of terms, we are statistically comparing the relationship of, say, lagged changes in employment with changes in air freight volume against lagged changes in air freight movement with changes in employment.

Looking at the simple pairwise regressions, and recalling they relate to null hypotheses, the F-statistics and associated probabilities that employment, income and personal income changes are not Granger causes of airfreight change are higher than those for airfreight change being the causal influence. As an example, we fail to reject the null hypothesis that first differences in the log of per capita income do not Granger cause the first difference in the log of per capita income, since the p-value (0.104) is more than 0.05. Put differently, there is no statistical evidence that changes in per capita income Granger cause changes in air freight volume. On the other hand, we should reject the null hypothesis that first differences in air freight volume do not Granger cause first difference in log of per capita income because of the p-value (0.043<0.05). This suggests that changes in airfreight volume do Granger cause changes in per capita income. In the same way, differences in the log airfreight volume Granger cause differences in the log of employment (a p-value of 0.002) and in the log of income (a p-value of 0.02). We also find that differences in the log of employment Granger cause variations in the log of airfreight volume (a p-value of 0.03), but this is not the case for either the log of income or of per capita income.

In summary, for pairs of air freight–per capital income and air freight–personal income, statistical evidence suggests that changes of airfreight volume Granger cause changes in the latter, but not vice versa. For the pair of air freight–employment, each variable could be the Granger cause of the other, but it is more difficult to reject the direction from the change of air freight volume to the change of employment because its p-value is much smaller than that of the reverse direction. Hence, airfreight transport emerges as a probably positive contributor to local economic development. Its growth is found to be a Granger cause of the change of local economic conditions, including employment, personal income and per capita income. The evidence that airfreight transport is endogenous to the economic growth process at the metropolitan level is much weaker.

sec.title: Usefulness of the Analysis
sec.p: While the transport community takes it as almost axiomatic that transport growth leads to wider economic development in a region, the evidence for this has largely been anecdotal. The application of income or employment multipliers, for example, take it as an act of faith that air services provide a stimulus for economic development; they are seen as positive exogenous shocks to the local economy. Testing for statistical causality is difficult, not least because of the need to hold background effects constant.

In a general sense, our findings are supportive of the idea that access to airfreight transport services can act as a positive stimulus to regional economic development through its tertiary and perpetuity effects. However, the tests can only be seen as meeting the criteria of necessary conditions; they are far from sufficient conditions. The data only cover a limited period and, although the pooling enriches the database, longer-term cycles are not well reflected. Additionally, the analysis does not embrace many of the other factors, such as labour and private capital stock, which are classical inputs in production function modelling and may well influence the economic development of regions; these can vary in their nature and importance over time, but are difficult to embody in causality testing.

The use of pooled time-series and cross-sectional data has the advantage of enhancing the information that can be used for analysis when only a decade or so of consistent statistics on air cargo are available. Yet it does have the problem that it does not really allow any separation of tertiary economic effects, the movement along the regional production function, from perpetuity effects, a shift in the function. These effects take longer to emerge and are, in any case, difficult to isolate when dealing with data on established airports rather than data from the time an airport facility was constructed.

From the perspective of assessing the validity of the two broad schools of thought on economic growth, the causality tests provide somewhat stronger support for the neo-classical model. If there were serious endogeneity, then one would have expected stronger positive causal links from the economic proxy variables to airfreight transport than are found. From a more meso planning and policy assessment perspective, the analysis offers some limited insights but importantly it does not consider the cost side of airfreight transport provision and, at the micro level, it does not provide any insight into which particular airfreight investments, or where, would yield the highest social return. For these factors to be taken into account in any economic development assessment, fuller benefit–cost analysis needs to be used. Certainly, the simple idea that “Build it and they will come”, to quote from the Kevin Costner movie, the appositely entitled Field of Dreams, is largely a fallacy that makes for good entertainment but not for good public policy formulation. The history of Mirabel airport in Canada offers the prime example of where major investment in air transport infrastructure did not bring traffic on anything like the scale envisaged and did virtually nothing for regional development.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Airfreight transport in the US is forecast to grow by 3.0 per cent per annum between 2010 and 2029 (Boeing Commercial Airplanes, 2009). For regional and state authorities, the challenge is to decide the extent to which they should try to attract some of this traffic as part of their regional development policies. If it is not going to stimulate local employment or income, then its active pursuit on pure economic grounds is not justified. The standard use of economic multipliers takes it for granted that airfreight service development can attract economic activity to a region and the focus becomes one of trying to gauge the size of the multiplier. Prior testing for causality is inevitably lacking. Statistically significant correlation is also generally easy to identify; the challenge is normally more one of deciding whether this is purely a spurious coincidence, or whether there are underlying causal linkages, and if so in what direction they run.

A better understanding of causality is helpful in policy-making in many areas and in particular regarding the factors that influence economic development, including the role of transport. The evidence here on airfreight is not conclusive, but rather indicative that it has a positive causal relationship with local economic development, although this is weak and certainly does not come anywhere close to matching Aschauer’s numbers for infrastructure more generally. It claims to show no more than a weak direction of causation, but it does at least potentially strengthen the foundation of much of the work that seeks to develop economically efficient transport policies in that there is a linkage.
